abstract: Vivian Maier's eye for midcentury street fashion - fox stoles, bonnets and bird-cage veils - made her something of a proto-Sartorialist.
snippet: Vivian Maier's eye for midcentury street fashion - fox stoles, bonnets and bird-cage veils - made her something of a proto-Sartorialist.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, a real estate agent, eBay peddler and amateur historian named John Maloof purchased 30,000 unattributed negatives on a hunch. This turned out to be the bulk of Vivian Maier's undiscovered oeuvre, virtuosic street photographs taken by a reclusive Chicago nanny who died quietly in 2009 at age 83, just before her work went viral. She is now considered to be a lost master of the form, the Windy City's own Helen Levitt. A giddy press has provided for her a whole slate of lofty comparisons: to Diane Arbus, Brassaï, Walker Evans and Weegee. Her eye for midcentury street fashion - fox stoles, bonnets and bird-cage veils - made her something of a proto-Sartorialist. But she could also slum it with street urchins, drooling bums and sideshow performers. Or mine the Loop late at night shooting perp walks.
